name: heavy mineral sand quarry operation | zircon | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/5657/documentation

This dataset refers to the production of 1 kg of zircon sand (reference product) and 1.286 kg of ilmenite and 0.409 kg of rutile (co-products) as a result mining and mineral separation activities applied on the heavy mineral sands (HMS). This dataset is based on the Gediga et al (2019) publication. According to that source, the dataset is meant to be a global average representation of the zircon sand production (data taken from 8 companies including 10 production sites, covering all major producing countries – Australia, South Africa, Kenya, Senegal and USA) representing 77% of the global situation.;The authors of the abovementioned publication acknowledge the existence of radioactive emissions, but their values were not provided. These emissions were included for completeness purposes and their respective amounts were taken from the previous existing dataset in Ecoinvent about the production of zircon sand (''heavy mineral sand quarry operation, GLO,2000-2005'' provided by Ecoinvent version 3.7 - see respective exchange comments). Due to lack of information, the exchange ''waste for recovery'' was approximated as non-sulfudic overburden, based on the information provided in Lundberg 2012 – where it is stated that 90% of the extracted materials return to the mining void. ;;Reference 1: Gediga, J., Morfino, A., Finkbeiner, M., Schulz, M., & Harlow, K. (2019). Life cycle assess-ment of zircon sand. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5.;;Reference 2: Lundberg, M. (2012). Environmental analysis of zirconium alloy production. (11061 Student thesis), Retrieved from http://urn.kb.se/resolve?urn=urn:nbn:se:uu:diva-166178 DiVA da-tabase.;;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - heavy mineral sand quarry operation, GLO, 2000 - 2005 (496f72b2-bf19-443a-806a-1ef7e188217b)];[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - heavy mineral sand quarry operation, GLO, 2019 - 2023 (d0fee673-ae20-4118-b835-40554e41201b)]

The activity starts with the mining of the heavy mineral sands.

The activity ends with the production of zircon sand, rutile and ilmenite.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: As mentioned in the general comment,  the dataset is meant to be a global average representation of the zircon sand production (data taken from 8 companies including 10 production sites, covering all major producing countries – Australia, South Africa, Kenya, Senegal and USA) representing 77% of the global situation.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: There are two ways for mining zircon sand: dry & wet mining with the choice of mining depending on the structure of the geological deposit. During wet mining, floating dredges and a floating concentrator are utilized in an enclosed pond, where the concentrator moves behind the dredges. Wet mining is the preferred technique for large continuous deposits with amounts of clay. ;For all other types of HMS deposits (hard-ground deposits, discontinuous deposits and small tonnage high-grade deposits), dry mining is the most preferred mining process. Dry mining utilizes earth-moving machinery (loaders, excavators, scrapes) for the purposes of sand excavation and transportation to the concentrator. The mining unit plants used in dry mining are mobile in order to minimize the transport distance of the sand. ;After the transportation of the HMS to the respective concentrator, wet gravity separations techniques (spirals) are usually applied for the production of the heavy mineral concentrate (HMC), although some hard-rock sites use bulk froth flotation to extract the heavy minerals from the sand. The produced slurry from dry and wet mining is then fed to the concentrator, where the HMC (90-96% heavy minerals) is produced along with the tailings that are backfilled in the mined areas. The HMC is transported to a mineral separation plant (MSP), where the HMC is subjected to scrubbing, drying and is separated by magnetic, electrostatic and gravity separation, producing zircon sand, ilmenite and rutile, with the last two considered as byproducts.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
As mentioned in the sampling procedure section, radioactive emissions were not considered in the Gediga et al (2019) publication. To account for these emissions, their amounts were taken from the dataset ''heavy mineral sand quarry operation, GLO,2000-2005'' provided by Ecoinvent version 3.7, which refers to the production of zircon sand (see also respective exchange comments).

Reference: Gediga, J., Morfino, A., Finkbeiner, M., Schulz, M., & Harlow, K. (2019). Life cycle assessment of zircon sand. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
The inputs and outputs considered here in this dataset are taken from Table 2 of the Gediga et al (2019) publication. The presented data in the publication are taken from 8 companies, representing 77% of the global production. For further information about the matching of the foreground data with the background data of Ecoinvent, please check the individual comments of each exchange. The authors of the abovementioned publication state that there are some radioactive emissions, however their values were not provided. To account for these emissions, the amount of radioactive emissions were taken from the previous existing dataset in Ecoinvent about the production of zircon sand (see respective exchange comments). The amounts of tailings (byproduct) has been slightly increased compared to the original value to ensure wet mass balance. The author's of the abovementioned publication acknowledge the existence of other byproducts from the production of the zircon sand, which were not mentioned in the source. However, those are considered minor and therefore those are also not contained in this dataset. Finally, due to the fact that waste products (i.e products that have a treatment activity in the database) cannot be used as inputs from technosphere, the tap water serves as a proxy also for the input of the wastewater.

Reference: Gediga, J., Morfino, A., Finkbeiner, M., Schulz, M., & Harlow, K. (2019). Life cycle assessment of zircon sand. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5.

exchanges.description: The value represents the production of zircon as a result of the mineral separation plant (MSP) activities. The value is taken from Table 2 of the following publication: Gediga, J., Morfino, A., Finkbeiner, M., Schulz, M., & Harlow, K. (2019). Life cycle assessment of zircon sand. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5. ). The value has been adjusted (compared to the original value reported) to represent the production of 1 kg of zircon.

exchanges.description: Input has been assumed for water balance purposes. Due to unknown consistency of the tailings associated with the zircon sand production, it has been assumed as worst-case scenario, that the mass of the tailings reported in the Gediga et al (2019) publication represents the dry mass of the tailings. This means that the original amount of the tailings (99.98 +1.10 =101.08 kg) will be dividied by 0.7 (dry mass of tailings) in order to calculate the total mass of the tailings with 0.7 dry mass (144.4 kg). Then the remaining mass that consists of water would originate from an unspecified water source (exchange: Water, unspecified natural origin) with the amount being equal to 0.3 (water in wet mass of the tailings multiplied by the previously calculated amount of tailings (144.4 kg).

exchanges.description: The amount of Silicon extracted from the ground is based on the following: i) The overall recovery rate of heavy minerals from the ore till the production of the final products (zircon, ilmenite and rutile) is 68% (Source: Mudd, G. M., & Jowitt, S. M. (2016). Rare earth elements from heavy mineral sands: assessing the potential of a forgotten resource. Applied Earth Science, 125(3), 107-113. doi:10.1080/03717453.2016.1194955). ii) The amount of Silicon contained in 1 kg zircon (ZrSiO4) is 0.1532 kg. (calculation based on the subtotal masses of ZrSiO4 where: Zr: 49.76%, Si:15.32%, O:34.91%. Source: ( https://www.lenntech.com/calculators/molecular/molecular-weight-calculator.htm )

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=GLO
The value represents the total diesel consumption from mining (0.03819 kg) and mineral separation plant (MSP) activities (1.03E-03 kg). The abovementioned values are taken from Table 2 of the following publication: Gediga, J., Morfino, A., Finkbeiner, M., Schulz, M., & Harlow, K. (2019). Life cycle assessment of zircon sand. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5. These values have been summed, converted to MJ (gross calorific value of diesel is 45.4 MJ/kg according toTable 5.1, chapter 5.6.3, page 35 of the data quality guidelines of Ecoinvent version 3) and adjusted (compared to the original values reported) to represent the production of 1 kg of zircon.

exchanges.description: The amount of gangue extracted from the ground is calculated by subtracting the amount of all individual metal contents (Zirconium, Hafnium, Titanium, Silicon and Iron) extracted from the ground from the amount of ore mined. The amount of mined ore (after aggregation of the mining and MSP activities and adjustment to correspond to 1 kg of zircon sand production) needed for the production of 1 kg of Zircon sand is 116.13 kg (Source: Table 2 of the following publication: Gediga, J., Morfino, A., Finkbeiner, M., Schulz, M., & Harlow, K. (2019). Life cycle assessment of zircon sand. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5).

exchanges.description:
Proxy considered for the exchange ''waste for recovery'' as recorded in Gediga et al (2019) as a byproduct from the mining activities. The value is taken from Table 2 of the previously mentioned source (analytical reference below). Due to lack of information about this waste, the approximation was based on the information provided in Lundberg (2012). According to that source, over 90% of the extracted materials return to the mining void. Based on this, the ''waste for recovery'' was approximated as non-sulfidic overburden. 

Reference 1: Gediga, J., Morfino, A., Finkbeiner, M., Schulz, M., & Harlow, K. (2019). Life cycle assessment of zircon sand. The Interna-tional Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5. The value has been adjust-ed (compared to the original value reported) to represent the production of 1 kg of zircon.

Reference 2: Lundberg, M. (2012). Environmental analysis of zirconium alloy production. (11061 Student thesis), Retrieved from http://urn.kb.se/resolve?urn=urn:nbn:se:uu:diva-166178 DiVA database.

exchanges.description: The amount of iron extracted from the ground is based on the following: i) The overall recovery rate of heavy minerals from the ore till the production of the final products (zircon, ilmenite and rutile) is 68% (Source: Mudd, G. M., & Jowitt, S. M. (2016). Rare earth elements from heavy mineral sands: assessing the potential of a forgotten resource. Applied Earth Science, 125(3), 107-113. doi:10.1080/03717453.2016.1194955). ii) The amount of iron contained in 1 kg of ilmenite (FeTiO3) is 0.1532 kg. (calculation based on the subtotal masses of FeTiO3 where: Fe: 31.86%, Ti:31.56%, Ο: 31.64%. Source: ( https://www.lenntech.com/calculators/molecular/molecular-weight-calculator.htm )

The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5. ). exchanges.description: The value represents the production of tailings as a result of the mining (99.98 kg) and mineral separation plant (MSP) activities (1.10 kg). The abovementioned values are taken from Table 2 of the following publication: Gediga, J., Morfino, A., Finkbeiner, M., Schulz, M., & Harlow, K. (2019). Life cycle assessment of zircon sand. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5.  Due to unknown consistency of the tailings associated with the zircon sand production, it has been assumed as worst-case scenario, that the mass of the tailings reported in the Gediga et al (2019) publication represents the dry mass of the tailings. This means that the original amount of the tailings (99.98 +1.10 =101.08 kg) will be dividied by 0.7 (dry mass of tailings) in order to calculate the total mass of the tailings with 0.7 dry mass (144.4 kg).

exchanges.description:
Due to the fact that waste products (i.e products that have a treatment activity in the database) cannot be used as inputs from technosphere, the tap water serves as a proxy also for the input of the wastewater. The consumption of wastewater during mining and mineral separation plant (MSP) process is 5.68 kg and 1.68 kg respectively. 
The consumption of tap water, during mineral separation plant (MSP) activities is 1.23 kg.The abovementioned values are taken from Table 2 of the following publication: Gediga, J., Morfino, A., Finkbeiner, M., Schulz, M., & Harlow, K. (2019). Life cycle assessment of zircon sand. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 24(11), 1976-1984. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01619-5. These values have been adjusted (compared to the original value reported) to represent the production of 1 kg of zircon sand.

exchanges.description: The amount of Titanium extracted from the ground is based on the following: i) The overall recovery rate of heavy minerals from the ore till the production of the final products (zircon, ilmenite and rutile) is 68% (Source: Mudd, G. M., & Jowitt, S. M. (2016). Rare earth elements from heavy mineral sands: assessing the potential of a forgotten resource. Applied Earth Science, 125(3), 107-113. doi:10.1080/03717453.2016.1194955). ii) The amount of Titanium contained in ilmenite (FeTiO3) and rutile (95% TiO2)  per 1 kg of each individual mineral is 0.3156 kg for ilmenite and 0.5993 kg for rutile (calculation based on the subtotal masses of FeTiO3 and TiO2. For ilmenite; Fe: 31.86%, Ti:31.56%, Ο: 31.64%. For rutile: Ti: 59.93%, O:40.06%. Source: https://www.lenntech.com/calculators/molecular/molecular-weight-calculator.htm ). The titanium contents of ilmenite and rutile are summed in the end for the calculation of the total amount of Titanium extracted from the ground.

exchanges.description: The amount of Zirconium extracted from the ground is based on the following: i) The overall recovery rate of heavy minerals from the ore till the production of the final products (zircon, ilmenite and rutile) is 68% (Source: Mudd, G. M., & Jowitt, S. M. (2016). Rare earth elements from heavy mineral sands: assessing the potential of a forgotten resource. Applied Earth Science, 125(3), 107-113. doi:10.1080/03717453.2016.1194955). ii) The amount of Zirconium contained in 1 kg zircon (ZrSiO4) is 0.4976 kg. (calculation based on the subtotal masses of ZrSiO4 where: Zr: 49.76%, Si:15.32%, O:34.91%. Source: ( https://www.lenntech.com/calculators/molecular/molecular-weight-calculator.htm )

flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in ground

exchanges.description: The amount of Hafnium extracted from the ground is based on the fact that the amount of Hafnium content is on average 2% of the zirconium content in zircon (Source: Nielsen RH, Wilfing G (2000) Hafnium and Hafnium Compounds. Ullmann’s Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry. Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA. Available: http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14356007.a12_559.pub2/abstract). Due to lack of data, it is assumed that the Hafnium content in ore is also 2% of the Zirconium content in ore. For the calculation of Zirconium content in ore, check the respective exchange comment.
